comments.commentBody: How is a dollar spent by the government different from a dollar spent by non-government? And aren't many dollars spent by the government spent on goods/services from the private sector. Seems to me that the $ I spend at the grocery stories the seam as the dollar spent by a SNAP recipient. Though I might purchase more things with a higher margin than the SNAP recipient. Or not? The professor also has noted - again and again - that the time for government to spend is when the private sector is not, and to cut back when the private sector is running at full production, in other words, replace a government $ with a private sector dollar. Trouble is the call for cutting now when the private sector has shown no inclination to spend more. Which isn't because the government is spending (note that the sequester has further cut discretionary spending that has already been cur under Obama) too much, but that no one is spending enough.for evidence, not the billions on corporate balance sheets - why would they use that money if they don't have demand? So it sits there. What multiplier does idle money have? It only multiplies if it's spent.

Thank you for your comment. It is refreshing to hear this instead of the assumption that Republican leadership just have a different method of a better economy. Rather as you point out, for the right, it is better for some people to fail and others to succeed regardless of the overall economy. However, it seems even Mr. Krugman takes the right's arguments seriously no matter how ridiculous the assertions. He should just assume if their proposals lead to a decline of the economy with some doing well, that is their intention.

Part of the problem is that US liberals believe in empathy and that everyone should be empathetic to all those in need. The right wing just blames the losers and pushes for more rules to create even more losers. I would jettison empathy as a political tool and talk about ethics. It is unethical to cheat workers out of deserved benefits and reward profiteering on the misery of others. Don't ameliorate the conditions of the poor, just don't allow poverty.

In the past right wing economists railed against full employment as inflationary. Although this was not true, it was important to exploit the labor force. With unemployment insurance, labor still costs too much for them compared with a workforce suffering deprivation.

We must dispense with pushing empathy or facts on people who do not value others as much as themselves. Instead, let us push against stealing from working people and finally outlaw poverty wages forever.

The punishment is not the cure, but an added bonus. The idea of causing pain came much later as the feedback loop of negativity really kicked in around the supply siders vision of creating a large low wage peasant class to help defeat organized labor. Norquist, Cheney and others saw that causing pain would help stir up the hatred of their base, as the doubled down on the policies the saw were failing.

The consequences of not extending unemployment benefits is significant It will be slowing down economic traction which comes from demand at the bottom. Like keeping the minimum wage below a livability standard for the 21st century, cutting benefits is just stupid. The bonus is it will cause a lot of pain and if many of their supports get hurt too; well they are just peasants after all. Like minimum wage laborers, expendable.

All in all a worst nightmare that will just keep on perpetuating the fundamentally flawed economic system with few more complicities with dubious language of the clever and uncouth lawyers and their master judges, like the Scalia nepotism. Notwithstanding that the AR hick Clinton is the one who is responsible for the repeal of the Glass-Steagall Act. That has led this misled and beguiled nation fiscally astray. Plus the corrupt to the hilt, self interest, self righteous US Congress, in which over 92% of the people have no confidence. in anything these second best to child molester and less then roaches do. Precisely why this misled and gullible nation of greed, waste and decadence need a need new Constitution and reformed Legislative, Judicial and Executive branches of the Government. Which this nation as a Republic, that is government of the people, by the people and for the people needs. That is the founding impetus that this nation is build upon.

The simple facts are that the trickery and thuggery that the money mongers have hatched and conjured up does not work, and why we are a indecent, ideologically divided, polarized nation on a fast track of self destruction from within.

@David....that's the scary part. You'd think as insecurity spreads, voters will demand redress. But maybe not. Instead the normal mechanisms of democracy won't work, b/c the gop rw will stir up the hatred of their base, and extend it to more voters, not against the real cause, but against the class below them, who are 'taking' from them. So more cuts to the poor and no remedies. That's how our politics let the inequality gap grow so large.

@Tara.... the body 'shuts down' hunger pangs if it lacks enough food? Why not? They said women's bodies 'shut down' the capacity to become pregnant from rape. It's magic.

Republicans are missing out on another argument: that food stamps cause hunger. That's right: over-dependence on food stamps increases food insecurity! Follow the logic, Mr. Rand...when someone is not eating properly, the body shuts down and becomes accustomed to less and less food. Giving that free-loader food stamps suddenly makes food available and, after the body adjusts to this new healthy diet, the loser in question will now experience hunger pangs! This is of course intolerable and must be stopped for their own good.

"Now, the G.O.P.’s desire to punish the unemployed doesn’t arise solely from bad economics; it’s part of a general pattern of afflicting the afflicted while comforting the comfortable (no to food stamps, yes to farm subsidies)."

I don't think there is much bad economics involved. Red herrings, distractions, Calvinistic moralizations, lack of compassion and understanding, greed--a lot of greed.

Three times as many job-seekers as jobs - and yet being unemployed is somehow *your* fault? Huge profits and cash balances in businesses, demand is depressed, and yet bigger business tax breaks are what is necessary to boost hiring? Food stamps are really welfare for the business class: they allow them to hire at wages no one could afford to work for otherwise, and yet it's the laborers who are looked down upon as opposed to the businesses who won't pay a living wage. McDonald's budget advice to workers: get a second job! And farm subsidies -- agra-business kickbacks.

Bad economics? I don't think so. That's just trying to redirect blame and avoid guilt. Most people don't go to Washington to serve anymore, they go to join the club and get rich, usually by making someone else richer still.
“The modern conservative is engaged in one of man's oldest exercises in moral philosophy; that is, the search for a superior moral justification for selfishness.”  JK Galbraith

It is probably a little more complicated than that.  Most of my friends are Republicans, otherwise good guys.  They are all incensed that the poor and the working poor have EBT cards, but are indifferent to the fact the the largest corporations in America pay little or no income tax.  They are highly critical of day laborers who they consider too lazy to hold down a full time job, but it is these very same laborers who they hire to do the jobs they don't want to do.  In fact laziness is a human condition; otherwise there would have been no inventions to make work easier.  The easiest jobs are the most sought after.  It is easier to sit behind a desk and make loans than to sweep and clean the bank.  The Republican/conservative mindset is one of little or no introspection.  And finally, it is a conservative condition to be "close minded".  In general they are not open to a new way of thinking.  On the other hand, the dictionary definition of Liberal is "Open Minded".  The good news is that most conservatives are older white guys, who won't live forever.  I have found that to try to reason with a Republican/conservative is senseless.  The best thing for me to do is to ignore them and on rare occasion when the situation is just right point how ludicrous their comments are.

db writes, "Most of my friends are Republicans, otherwise good guys. "
They CANNOT be both, that is like saying 'He's a good Christian, who hates gay folks', and someone needs to tell them that they are bad folks who wish ill on little children. We need to call a spade a spade, and not allow them to run around amongst us thinking that what they believe is acceptable to anyone with a functioning heart and brain. Their votes increase the number of children going to bed hungry, and most of these children's parents just want a job, and many of their parents already work, but for such piddling wages that after paying rent and the light bill, they can't always buy groceries. If someone was standing on the sidewalk tripping people as they walk by we would shun that person. I see the deeds being done by Republican votes as more sinister than this, because they are tripping generations, both the young and old, and many in between. They should be publically shamed!!

I think I am beginning to see a pattern in these oppositions to Social Security Medicare, Medicaid, unemployment insurance, and just about any help earned or deserved by the right wing coalitions in the U.S.

It has all the contents of an underlying morality that is fueled by puritanical psychopathy. In the minds of those who oppose such programs, the recipients are not deserving of them.

Social Security, they say, you should have saved up enough so that you do not need it. Same for those thrown out of work, you were remiss for having failed to account for the possibility.

In their minds, those who get such help do not deserve it, and are just "taking" it from the god productive citizens, in effect, stealing their money in the form of taxes. And as we hear from these churlish people, they believe it all needs to be done away with..

Arguments about ideology and unemployment benefits are largely beside the point. The real motives behind this latest Republican outrage along with two debt limit crises, the sequester, the shutdown, opposition to SNAP, failure to pass a farm bill, etc. are conscious efforts to kill the economic recovery. They want to retake control of the government with the argument that Democrats have failed to fix the economic meltdown of 2006-07. It may well work since President Obama and other Democrats appear unable or unwilling to make an issue of the obvious.

Speaking of seeing another, didn't you use that avatar recently? Not the photo (which was a bench); but in the reveal for that one, I thought you mentioned 2 other works of art.

Ahh, there's the subtext: That this XWP aka "Monday Stumper" was a work of art?

Amen. These "trade agreements" that give cover to the DINOs of our time (and we're going to go for another one?!) are misnomers; they are cartel agreements, and not only corporate giveaways and protectionism of a different sort, but they are, as you state, also giveaways of our national sovereignty. And state sovereignty as well (funny we don't hear a peep out of our "states' rights" politicians...), whereby state and local review and permitting processes, an exercise of law by a state's citizenry, are under facial assault by the WTO and other trade agreement enforcers (e.g., coal train impacts in the Northwest).

The blatant looting of this country's treasure and hijacking of its principles (admittedly time-honored sport of the ruling class) are astonishing. And their witting and unwitting abetment by the best politicians money can buy is doubly so.

My friends and I are planning on leaving the US for greener pastures as soon as we get our STEM Masters' and PhDs in hand. Will we come back? Maybe to visit. We're quickly becoming the norm not the exception. Maybe if the US valued our knowledge and experience we by employing us in jobs we are highly qualified for, we would not feel the need to leave. But the signs are clear, we're not wanted nor needed.

With this news, it's clear how utterly our two-party system is failing us, that we may need a massive overhaul of our government and elections to survive as a nation. The callousness, spite and sociopathy of the Republican Party are well known, but what's shocking is how the Democrats are not only rolling over in the face of GOP threats, but even actively supporting their moves to cut food stamps, critical unemployment benefits and other fraying safety nets.

In fact it seems now that President Obama's top legislative priority has been ramming through the repulsive Trans-Pacific Partnership trade agreement, which he's conveniently "classified" and restricted to secret negotiations, and which (based on recent document leaks) is an open attempt to impose fascism on the USA and nearly a dozen other nations, with corporations trumping even basic national sovereignty. That and (with the help of deluded Democratic Senators like Chuck Schumer and Amy Klobuchar) lobbying for still more corrupt H-1B visas to wreck the US domestic tech industry and drive down wages and jobs.

Our STEM and other skilled workers are emigrating from the USA in droves; many of my best ex-engineering students are now in Scandinavia, the Netherlands, Belgium, France, Germany, Switzerland, Korea, even as far afield as China and South America, and most will never return. Not because those are perfect places, but because most them have at least avoided the corporate madness that's strangling US democracy.

"What convinced Kasher and Greenberg to take Vivian Maier's champion seriously?"

Nothing short of the eventual recognition of the depth and breadth of her talent and legacy- and all the $$$ to be made from it...

Chickadee- I think blaming the memorials in and of themselves as promoting violence or retaliation is a bit of a stretch- a long one.

I think the wholesale abandonment of these neighborhoods, and more importantly, the people that live within them are more to the point. This is a complex problem with a lot of blame to go around, but as long as people who do not live in these neighborhoods continue to think that it's not their problem, the longer this particular problem will continue to fester, grow- and reach out to them.

A couple of comments: First, Morales continues to wear both hats, president of Bolivia and president of the association of coca growers; second, the coca grown in the Yungas region produces more than enough coca for all Bolivia's legal consumption; and third to suggest that the coca growers of Challa are doing it to improve the local economy and that their "vision is innocent" is very naive. Most, if not all, the production of coca outside the Yungas region is for the manufacture of cocaine.

The picture of the young girls in India broke my heart … but then my heart was quickly mended again. Maybe, just maybe, humankind can be cured of racism forever. (To me this image is one of the most profound Lens has ever shown. Thanks NYTimes.)

Are you kidding? "All of that spending recycles back into the economy and creates employment"
Why not break all the window and the country and everyone would have a job!
Every dollar government spends comes OUT of the private sector decreasing employment.

A key reason for providing unemployment benefits is that people who are receiving 40% to 50% of their prior pay spend all of the money they receive.  The money is spent on rent, mortgage payments, fuel, transportation, food, basic clothing, ancillary educational expenses, taxes other than income and payroll taxes and so forth.  All of that spending recycles back into the economy and creates employment.
Made me laugh out loud.
I slept with my grand parents to give my parents privacy, I now realise. Just some input from a more traditional culture. And they told me stories every night, I miss them.

Why would it matter to you if you leave them the land and it turns out that they will have certain challenges to face in using it? To be perfectly frank, you will not be there for it to be a problem for you.

I think if they have expressed an interest in having the land (and it's not like 17 acres is that big a deal) then deciding that you think it's not in their best interests to have it can only alienate them from you.

Sounds like she was happy to pilfer the money, but resents your offering it.  Offer no more.  Do send cards and thoughtful but small gifts (movie gift cards for the kids, maybe?) so they know they are thought of.

I live in a different city than my sister and have had little contact with her. She has a chaotic family life including some grandchildren in foster care and many near the poverty line. I am  the youngest of six, relatively well off and the only college graduate (no one bothered to  come to my graduation).  Last Christmas,  because my mother was dying. I came to my birth city. I stayed in a hotel and paid for gas and meals with family. I also brought each of the 20 children and grandchildren a gift bag with candy and $20.00 cash, which I left with my sister to distribute. (I also gave this sister $400.00 for herself). Before I left, I found out, inadvertently from this sister and directly from my 19 year old nephew that she  had, just like the GRINCH, pilfered the childrens' money for herself! Now that Christmas is here again, I will not be giving her anything. Should I try to give  the older children money directly (she might get her hands on it)? Also, she has spread the rumor that I am trying to 'buy love'  even though I have very little contact with her family.

We gave up the tree. Chopping off a live tree for a few weeks of decoration or festooning up some artificial contraption did not make us feel very cheerful anymore. No more empty spot underneath the tree that begs to be filled with presents. There are so many cute ways to dress up a house or room for Christmas these days. The use of music and a few candles are one simple way.
Very interesting and beautiful story... So many changes and a commitment that endured... Congratulations and may there be many good years to come!

Like the line from 1776 by Stone and Edwards:

John Dickinson: Don't forget that most men with nothing would rather protect the possibility of becoming rich than face the reality of being poor.

If one provides assistance to the needy, it suggests that they do not deserve their poor luck. And if they don't deserve it, then the possibility exists that we, too, may become poor.

Agreed except for the New York part, NY has few Republicans in power compared to some of the other states you name, especially on the state level and in larger cities. Plus two quite good US senators, either of whom I would take in a heartbeat over PA's club for growth junior senator and sure looking like tea party adherent governor. The challenge in many states is for Democrats to get out the vote in off year elections, which is where the entrenched GOP machine shines in much of the smaller population centers, enabling them to dominate state politics.

Unless these "exhaustive studies" exist in some very secret space, there are none... There might be a legitimate argument about the size of the multiplier, but the number of less than 1 requires the money to be physically (or, now, electronically) destroyed - for a 0.8 number you are quoting, the worker gets say $100 in twenties, spends or invests $80 and feeds the last twenty into the shredder.

Number of available work hours less than number of available worker hours = unemployment (actively seeking and discouraged).  Morality, incentives, rhetoric, common sense & intuition cannot over-ride that inequality.

Challenges are fun to encourage --for others--when you, yourself, are employed.

The 1% own the campground, the restaurant, the dumpster into which garbage is tossed, and the bear. They shut the rest of us out of jobs in the restaurant or cleaning the campground, and now they intend to padlock the dumpster.

"See that bear?" they smile. "Go into the woods and find grubs and berries, like he does!"
Of course there's absolutely no psychological significance in the fact that you compare some of your fellow citizens with animals...

A wild grizzly bear is magnificent wild hunter but if you temp him with human garbage this apex predator will quickly choose garbage over hunting and just sit next to the campground and become a beggar. Many humans are no different. Giving them easy money and food destroys any work ethic and they will choose watching TV and collecting food stamps/welfare over productive employment. Every rational person who has any experience knows this to be true. The real challenge is to somehow differentiate temporary help from life destructive dependency. Giving unemployment benefits for maybe up to six months is one thing but two years is a fool's errand that is sure to ultimately cause more harm than good. Life is a challenge and when you remove all the challenges you create grizzly bears that dumpster dive rather than run down elk and you destroy the essence of what it means to be a grizzly bear.
